This book will deal with all the topics covered in the high school syllabus, through numerical problems and other questions. Unlike a textbook which teaches students, we expect the content of this book to teach students to teach themselves.
The articles, problems and solutions discussed here will focus on the thought process rather than the steps involved. The second goal of this problem book is to make students realize that Chemistry is indeed simpler than Physics, Mathematics and Biology at the highschool level.
Presently, this book is randomly edited as per the questions put forward to the contributors. As we submit more and more content, we will start integrating the pieces into a picture. Volunteers are welcome to discuss the content policy, make contributions, and above all - giving touch ups to the already submitted content.
=== Basic Topics ===
=== Inorganic Chemistry ===
=== Physical Chemistry ===
==== First Law Of Thermodynamics ==== *[[/PhChem/thermo1/intro/|An Introduction]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/table/|Problems on the next level]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/Problem1/|Problem 1]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/Splmntry/|Supplementary Problems on work]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/splmntry2/|Supplementary problems on work, variations]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/advsiso/|Graphs of adiabatic and isothermal processes]] *[[/PhChem/thermo1/problem2/|Problem 2]]
==== Second Law Of Thermodynamics ====
==== Chemical Kinetics ====
==== Radioactivity ====
==== Vapour Pressure ====
==== Colligative Properties of Solutions ====
==== Surface Chemistry ====
==== Solid State ====
==== Chemical Equilibrium ====
==== Introduction to Ionic Equilibrium ====
==== Ionic Equilibrium - Level II ====
==== Electrolytic Conductance ====
==== Electrochemistry : Electrodes and Reactions ====
==== Electrochemistry : Electrolytic Cells and Electrolysis ====
=== Organic Chemistry ===

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Learning the vi editor/Vim/VimL Script language]] to [[Talk:Learning the vi Editor/Vim/VimL Script language]]: Title casing.
revision.text: ==Why "Exim"?== I don't know where the idea that Vim's scripting language was called "Exim" came from. Conventionally on the Vim mailing lists it's been referred to as "Vim script(ing)" or just "VimL"—if you were to call it "Exim" there you'd probably confuse everybody, including [[wikipedia:Bram Moolenaar|Bram]], the developer and copyright owner of Vim. The only references to "exim" in the Vim help files are for the command-line equivalent of invoking "vim -E" (ex mode), and while Vim scripts are interpreted as if you had typed all the commands in ex mode that still doesn't justify arbitrarily naming the scripting language "Exim". Further confusing the issue, [[wikipedia:Exim|Exim is a mail transfer agent]]. -- [[User:Heptite|Heptite]] 20:50, 2 September 2007 (UTC) :Since there's been no disagreement (indeed, no discussion at all) on this subject, I went ahead and just moved the subarticle/submodule. -- [[User:Heptite|Heptite]] ([[User talk:Heptite|talk]]) 16:58, 4 February 2008 (UTC)

revision.text:
==First-Order Logic== In propositional logic, we considered formulas made about atomic objects, which could only be either true or false. First-order logic, the topic of this chapter, builds upon propositional logic and allows you to look inside the objects discussed in formulas. We can provide this more refined level of granularity by discussing objects as elements of sets that can be larger than just the set <math>\{0, 1\}</math>, and also include arbitrarily complex relationships with each other.
We begin first by defining the syntax of first-order (FO) logic, and then give these structures meaning.
===Syntax=== The domain of discourse for first order logic is first-order structures or models. A '''first-order structure''' contains # Relations, # Functions, and # Constants (functions of arity 0).
The vocabulary of first-order logic is # a set of relation symbols with associated arities, and # a set of function symbols with associated arities.
Here are some example first-order logic vocabularies: # A graph #* Relation Set = { <math>V</math> : unary, <math>E</math> : binary } #* Function Set = { <math>\mathit{next}</math> : unary } # Arithmetic #* Relation Set = { <math>+</math> : ternary, <math>\times</math> : ternary, <math>\uparrow</math> : ternary, <math>=</math> : binary, <math><</math> : binary} #*Function Set = { <math>\mathit{next}</math> : unary, <math>0</math> : const }
Here, a graph is a set of vertices <math>V</math> and a set of edges <math>E</math>. For the arithmetic set note that the use of <math>+</math> and <math>\times</math> is purely syntactic and we could have used the symbols "plus" and "times" instead. We haven't provided the symbols with any meaning yet.
A '''term''' denotes an element in the first-order structure. A term is used to refer to the elements in our domain of discourse. Here are the rules that describe what a term is: * every variable is a term, where a variable is simply another set of symbols * every constant is a term * If <math>t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k}</math> are terms, and <math>f</math> is a <math>k</math>-ary function then <math>f(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k})</math> is a term. For example, if <math>f</math> is a binary function and <math>g</math> is a ternary function then the following are all terms: <math>x, a, f(x, y), g(x, f(x, y), a)</math>.
An '''atomic formula''' is :<math>R(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k})</math>, where <math>R</math> is a <math>k</math>-ary relation and <math>t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k}</math> are terms. When viewing <math>R</math> as a set, then this is just another way of saying that the tuple :<math>(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k})\in R</math>.
A special relation <math>=</math> means "equal" and cannot be interpreted otherwise. For example, <math>t_{1} = t_{2}</math> stands for :<math>=(t_{1}, t_{2})</math>.
A first-order '''formula''' is an expression built using a given first-order vocabulary and variables and the symbols <math>(, ), \neg, \vee, \wedge, \rightarrow, \exists, \forall</math>. The set of first-order formulas is the minimum set satisfying the following: * atomic formulas are first order formulas * If <math>\phi</math> and <math>\psi</math> are formulas and <math>x</math> is a variable, then the following are also formulas: #<math>(\phi \vee \psi)</math> #<math>(\phi \wedge \psi)</math> #<math>(\neg \phi)</math> #<math>(\phi \rightarrow \psi)</math> #<math>(\exists x \phi)</math> #<math>(\forall x \phi)</math>
===Semantics=== A first-order structure over a given vocabulary consists of # A domain, which is a set of elements (also known as a universe) # A mapping associating to every <math>k</math>-ary relation symbol in the vocabulary a <math>k</math>-ary relation over the domain, and to every <math>k</math>-ary function symbol a <math>k</math>-ary function over the domain. These components give meaning to the symbols.
Example: :Relation Set = { <math>+</math> : ternary, <math>\times</math> : ternary, <math>\uparrow</math> : ternary, <math>=</math> : binary, <math><</math> : binary } :Function Set = { <math>next</math> : unary, <math>0</math> : const } A first-order structure over this vocabulary is: # Domain: the set of integers # Mapping : <math>+ \rightarrow</math> addition, <math>\times \rightarrow</math> multiplication, <math>\uparrow \rightarrow</math> exponentiation, <math>< \rightarrow</math> ordering, <math>\mathit{next} \rightarrow i+1</math>
In this structure, the formula :<math>\exists x \forall y \forall z[\times (y, z, x) \rightarrow ((y = 1) \vee (z = 1))]</math> expresses the statement "there exists a prime number" (the number 1 also satisfies this statement).
Note here that <math>\times (y, z, x)</math> is equivalent to <math>(x = y \times z)</math>.
====Scope of Quantifiers==== In the formula <math>(\forall x \phi)</math> or <math>(\exists x \phi)</math>, <math>\phi</math> is referred to as the scope of quantification of the variable <math>x</math>. An occurrence of a variable in a formula is bound if it is in the scope of quantification of that variable, otherwise the occurrence is said to be free. You can consider a quantifier use as a variable declaration.
A '''sentence''' is a formula with no free variables (i.e., all variables are bound). A sentence is either true or false.
A formula with free variable(s) can be considered as describing the properties of the free variable(s). For example, <math>\phi(x)</math> denotes a formula with <math>x</math> occurring free and describes the properties of <math>x</math>.
If a sentence <math>\phi</math> evaluates to true over a structure <math>I</math>, we say <math>I</math> satisfies <math>\phi</math> and denote this by <math>I \models\phi</math>.
*<math>I \models R(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k})</math> iff <math>(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{k}) \in I(R)</math>, where <math>I(R)</math> is the interpretation of <math>R</math> by <math>I</math>. *<math>I \models \phi \wedge \psi</math> iff <math>I \models \phi</math> and <math>I \models \psi</math>. (Similar for <math>\vee</math>.) *<math>I \models \neg \varphi</math> iff <math>I \not\models \varphi</math>. *<math>I \models \exists x \phi(x)</math> if <math>I \models \phi(x \leftarrow c)</math> for some <math>c</math> in the domain. *<math>I \models \forall x \phi(x)</math> if <math>I \models \phi(x \leftarrow c)</math> for every <math>c</math> in the domain.
Note: <math>\phi(x \leftarrow c)</math> denotes the result of substituting <math>c</math> for every free occurrence of <math>x</math> in <math>\phi</math>. Substitution is covered further later in this chapter.
===Axiomatic approach=== The '''axioms''' are a set of sentences meant to distinguish "desired" models from others. But typically, also have "undesired" models, which are called non-standard models.
Examples: Consider the vocabulary <math>(\mathit{next}, +, \times, \uparrow, 0, =, <)</math>, where the symbols have the usual meaning (defined by FO sentences over this vocabulary). The standard interpretation for this set of axioms (see the end of this chapter) is the integers, but these are also satisfied by the set of integers modulo <math>p</math>. This possibility is ruled out by adding the following sentence to the axioms: <math>\forall x (x < \mathit{next}(x))</math>
Question: Can all non-standard models be axiomatized away? The answer is no. Consider the model shown in [TODO: import figure] for the vocabulary containing only <math>0,<,\sigma</math> (all elements in the upper line are larger than those on the lower line).
There is no set of first-order sentences that can distinguish this model from the natural numbers. Intuitively, the reason is that we cannot "backtrack" arbitrarily (towards <math>0</math>) in a first-order sentence. A similar non-standard model can be obtained for the full vocabulary above.
===Evaluating FO Sentences=== Given a first-order structure <math>I</math> and a FO sentence <math>\phi</math>, can we tell if <math>I \models \phi</math>?
This problem is decidable for finite structures. For example, suppose <math>E</math> is a binary relation representing the edges of a graph, and the given sentence is :<math>\exists x_{1} \exists x_{2} \exists x_{3}(E(x_{1}, x_{2}) \wedge E(x_{2}, x_{3}) \wedge E(x_{3}, x_{1}) \wedge x_{1} \neq x_{2} \wedge x_{2} \neq x_{3} \wedge x_{3} \neq x_{1} )</math>. We can evaluate the truth of this sentence by trying all possible values for <math>x_{1}, x_{2}</math> and <math>x_{3}</math>. (Naive evaluation: "nested loop".) This is polynomial time (in domain size) but exponential in the size of the formula.
On infinite domains, we may or may not be able to evaluate the truth of a sentence. With the vocabulary <math>(N, 0, \sigma, <, +)</math>, where <math>N</math> is the set of natural numbers, it is decidable if a sentence is true. (This is known as Presburger arithmetic.) However if we include multiplication, the truth of a sentence becomes undecidable.
===A Deductive System for FO=== A set <math>\Delta</math> of FO sentences is * Satisfiable if there is some structure <math>I</math> such that <math>I \models \Delta</math> * Unsatisfiable if it is not satisfiable * Valid if <math>I \models \Delta</math> for all structure <math>I</math>
Given a set of FO sentences <math>\Sigma</math> and a sentence <math>\phi</math> * <math>\Sigma</math> entails <math>\phi</math> (denoted <math>\Sigma \models \phi</math>), if every structure that satisfies <math>\Sigma</math> also satisfies <math>\phi</math>. * <math>\Sigma \models \phi</math> iff <math>\Sigma \cup \{\neg \phi\}</math> is unsatisfiable. * If <math>\Sigma</math> is finite then, <math>\Sigma \models \phi</math> iff <math>\neg \Sigma \lor \phi</math> is valid. * If a formula <math>\phi</math> has free variables <math>\vec{X} = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k})</math>, <math>\phi</math> is valid iff <math>\forall \vec{X} \phi</math> is valid.
====Axioms for Validity==== The axioms for validity are from three categories: # Axioms for boolean validity. These are inherited from propositional logic. # Axioms for equality. # Axioms for quantification.
=====Boolean Validity===== Given a FO formula <math>\varphi</math>, a boolean form of <math>\varphi</math> a propositional formula <math>\psi</math> such that <math>\varphi</math> is obtained from <math>\psi</math> by replacing each propositional variable in <math>\psi</math> by a subformula of <math>\varphi</math>.
The set of Boolean forms of <math>\varphi</math> is denoted <math>BF(\varphi)</math>.
Examples: * For the FO formula <math>\forall x P(x) \lor \neg \forall x P(x)</math>, the boolean form is <math>p \lor \neg p</math>. * If <math>\varphi \equiv \forall x G(x,y) \land \exists x G(x,y) \land (G(z,x) \lor \forall x G(x,y)) </math>, then <math>BF(\varphi) \equiv x_{1} \land x_{3} \land (x_{2} \lor x_{1}) </math> where <math>x_1 = \forall x G(x,y), x_2 = G(z,x), x_3 = \exists x G(x,y)</math>.
'''Claim''': If <math>\psi \in BF(\varphi)</math> and <math>\psi</math> is valid, then <math>\varphi</math> is valid.
=====Equality Axioms===== Let <math>t, t_{1}, \ldots, t_{k}, t'_{1}, \ldots, t'_{k}</math> be terms. The following are valid formulas.
* <math>t = t</math> * <math>(t_{1} = t'_{1} \land \cdots \land t_{k} = t'_{k}) \rightarrow (f(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{k}) = f(t'_{1}, \ldots, t'_{k}))</math>, where <math>f</math> is a <math>k</math>-ary function. * <math>(t_{1} = t'_{1} \land \cdots \land t_{k} = t'_{k}) \rightarrow (R(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{k}) \rightarrow R(t'_{1}, \ldots, t'_{k}))</math>, where <math>R</math> is a <math>k</math>-ary relation.
=====Substitutions===== Given a formula <math>\varphi</math> in which variable <math>x</math> occurs free (denoted by <math>\varphi(x)</math>) and a term <math>t</math>, we define the substitution of <math>t</math> for <math>x</math> in <math>\varphi</math>, denoted <math>\varphi(x \leftarrow t)</math>, as the formula that results from replacing every free occurrence of <math>x</math> in <math>\varphi</math> by <math>t</math>, subject to the constraint that <math>t</math> contains no variable <math>y</math> quantified in <math>\varphi</math> such that <math>x</math> occurs free within the scope of quantification of <math>y</math>. If <math>x</math> does not occur free <math>\varphi</math>, then <math>\varphi(x \leftarrow t)</math> is defined as <math>\varphi</math>.
Example: Let <math>\varphi</math> be :<math>((x = 1) \rightarrow \exists x (x = y))</math>, then *<math>\varphi(x \leftarrow (y + 1))</math> is a valid substitution *<math>\varphi(y \leftarrow (x + 1))</math> is not a valid substitution.
=====Quantification Axioms===== #<math>\forall x \varphi \rightarrow \varphi(x \leftarrow t)</math>, where <math>t</math> is a term and <math>\varphi(x \leftarrow t)</math> is a valid substitution #<math>(\forall x (\varphi \rightarrow \psi)) \rightarrow ((\forall x \varphi) \rightarrow (\forall x \psi))</math> #<math>\varphi \rightarrow \forall x \varphi</math> #<math>\exists x \varphi \leftrightarrow \neg \forall x \neg \varphi</math>
In summary, the axioms for validity are <math>{\mathbf {Ax}}</math>: #Axioms for boolean validity. These are inherited from propositional logic. #Axioms for equality. #Axioms for quantification.
'''Definition''': A ''proof'' is a sequence <math>\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \ldots, \phi_{k}</math> of FO sentences such that for each <math>i \in \{1, \ldots, k\}</math> either <math>\phi_{i} \in{\mathbf {Ax}}</math> or <math>\exists j, k < i</math> such that <math>\phi_{j} \equiv \psi</math> and <math>\phi_{k} \equiv (\psi \rightarrow \phi_{i})</math>.
'''Notation''': If there is a proof of <math>\phi</math> using <math>{\mathbf{Ax}}</math>, we denote this fact by <math>\vdash_{\mathbf {Ax}}\phi</math>.
'''Fact''' (Soundness): If <math>\vdash_{\mathbf {Ax}} \phi</math>, then <math>\phi</math> is valid.
'''Remark''': The set of formulas which can be proven valid is recursively enumerable.
Example: Proof of the formula <math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow (\forall x \phi \land \forall x \psi)</math>
:<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi)</math> :<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow (\phi \land \psi) (x \leftarrow x)</math> :<math>\phi \land \psi</math> :<math>\phi</math> :<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow \phi</math> :<math>\forall x (\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow \phi)</math> :<math>\forall x \forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow \forall x \phi</math> :<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow \forall x \phi</math> :<math>\forall x \phi</math> The proof of <math>\forall x \psi</math> is symmetrical. :<math>\forall x \phi \land \forall x \psi</math> :<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \rightarrow (\forall x \phi \land \forall x \psi)</math>
====Useful Equivalences==== *<math>\forall x (\phi \land \psi) \leftrightarrow (\forall x \phi) \land (\forall x \psi)</math> *<math>\forall x (\phi \lor \psi) \not\leftrightarrow (\forall x \phi) \lor (\forall x \psi)</math> e.g. <math>\phi(x) \approx</math> "x is even" and <math>\psi(x)\approx</math> "x is odd" *<math>\forall x (\phi(x) \lor \neg \phi(x)) \not\leftrightarrow (\forall x \phi(x) \lor \forall x \neg \phi(x))</math> *<math>\exists x (\phi \lor \psi) \leftrightarrow (\exists x \phi) \lor (\exists x \psi)</math> *<math>\neg \exists x \phi \leftrightarrow \forall x \neg \phi</math> *<math>\neg \forall x \phi \leftrightarrow \exists x \neg \phi</math>
====Prenex Normal Form==== '''Claim''': Every FO sentence is equivalent to a FO sentence of the form <math>Q_{1} x_{1} \cdots Q_{k} x_{k} \phi</math>, where <math>Q_{i} \in \{\exists, \forall \}</math> and <math>\phi</math> is quantifier free.
This is proved using the distributive properties of quantifiers. It may be necessary to rename variables, to avoid ambiguities. Although you can always move all quantifiers to the left, the resulting formula can actually be exponentially larger than the original one.
'''Example''': :<math>\phi \equiv \forall x (G(x,x) \land (\forall y G(x,y) \lor \exists y \neg G(y,y))) \land G(x,0)</math> ::<math>\equiv (\forall x (G(x,x) \land (\forall y G(x,y) \lor \exists y \neg G(y,y)))) \land G(w,0)</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x (G(x,x) \land (\forall y G(x,y) \lor \exists y \neg G(y,y)) \land G(w,0))</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x (G(x,x) \land (\forall y G(x,y) \lor \exists z \neg G(z,z)) \land G(w,0))</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x (G(x,x) \land \forall y (G(x,y) \lor \exists z \neg G(z,z)) \land G(w,0))</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x \forall y (G(x,x) \land (G(x,y) \lor \exists z \neg G(z,z)) \land G(w,0))</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x \forall y (G(x,x) \land \exists z (G(x,y) \lor \neg G(z,z)) \land G(w,0))</math> ::<math>\equiv\forall x \forall y \exists z (G(x,x) \land (G(x,y) \lor \neg G(z,z)) \land G(w,0))</math>
====Recall the Axiomatic Method==== # Describe the desired model as closely as possible using a (possibly infinite but recursive) set <math>\Delta</math> of axioms (FO sentences).
#Prove things using deduction.
'''Notation''': We say <math>\phi</math> is a valid consequence of <math>\Delta</math> (denoted <math>\Delta \models \phi</math>), if every model satisfying <math>\Delta</math> also satisfies <math>\phi</math>.
'''Fact''': <math>\Sigma \models \phi</math> iff <math>\Sigma \cup \{\neg \phi\}</math> is unsatisfiable.
===Aside: Nonlogical axioms for number theory===
The following fourteen first-order axioms describe the properties of arithmetic and numbers, i.e. addition (<math>+</math>), multiplication (<math>\times</math>), exponentiation (<math>\uparrow</math>, equality (<math>=</math>), ordering (<math><</math>), successor function (<math>\sigma</math>) and remainder (mod). This example shows the expressive power of first-order statements, which were originally hoped to provide a basis for the "one true mathematics."
Question: Why are they called "nonlogical" axioms?
:NT1: <math>\forall x(\sigma(x) \ne 0)</math> :NT2: <math>\forall x \forall y (\sigma(x) = \sigma(y) \rightarrow x=y)</math> :NT3: <math>\forall x (x=0 \vee \exists y \sigma(y) = x)</math> :NT4: <math>\forall x (x+0=x) </math> :NT5: <math>\forall x \forall y(x+\sigma(y) = \sigma(x+y)) </math> :NT6: <math>\forall x (x\times 0 = 0) </math> :NT7: <math>\forall x \forall y (x\times \sigma(y) = (x \times y ) + x) </math> :NT8: <math>\forall x ( x \uparrow 0 = \sigma(0)) </math> :NT9: <math>\forall x \forall y (x \uparrow \sigma(y) = (x \uparrow y ) \times x ) </math> :NT10: <math>\forall x (x<\sigma(x)) </math> :NT11: <math>\forall x \forall y ( x < y \rightarrow (\sigma (x)\le y)) </math> :NT12: <math>\forall x \forall y ( \neg (x<y) \leftrightarrow y \le x) </math> :NT13: <math>\forall x \forall y \forall z (((x<y) \wedge (y<z)) \rightarrow x<z) </math> :NT14: <math>\forall x \forall y \forall z \forall z' (mod(x,y,z)\wedge mod(x,y,z') \rightarrow z = z') </math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]
#REDIRECT [[Logic for Computer Science]]

<center> <big><big>Introduction to the Scientific Method</big></big> </center> ----
In Ecology, as with many sciences a series of steps known as the [[w:scientific_method|scientific method]] are involved in trying to support or nullify a hypothesis.
There are two ways to support your hypothesis. The first way is by a weak inference, which is basically using one distinct hyptohesis and trying to support that hypothesis through observation. The other way is by using strong inference. This method is regarded as having more credibility as it uses numerous hypotheses with a null hypothesis for each. Instead of trying to support one hypothesis as with a weak inference, the researcher tries to disprove numerous hypotheses through controlled experimentation to support a single hypothesis.
{{BookCat}}

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Cuisine of India]] {{recipesummary |Category = Indian recipes |Time = preparation: 20 minutes
maturing: 1 month |Servings = about a pint of pickle |Rating = 2 |Image = [[Image:Lemon pickle star anise.jpg|300px]] }} '''Lemon pickle''' is a traditional condiment used with [[Cookbook:Cuisine of India|Indian]] food. Many pickle recipes from India have oil to help preserve the pickle, but this recipe uses no oil. {{see also|Cookbook:Lemon Pickle}} ==Ingredients== * [[Cookbook:Lemon|lemons]] - 8 small or 4 large * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] of [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * ¼ - ½ cup of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 4 small green [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chilis]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Mustard|yellow mustard]] seed * 1 tablespoon ground [[Cookbook:Mustard|ginger]] * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Fenugreek|fenugreek]] seed * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|tsp]] [[Cookbook:Turmeric|turmeric]] powder * 1 - 2 [[Cookbook:Star Anise|star anise]] ==Procedure== # Cut lemons into small pieces, and place in a bowl. # Cover with salt and set aside for at least 4 hours (better 24!) # Chop the chilis finely. # Dry-roast the yellow mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, star anise, and chopped chilis on a high heat, shaking constantly - don't burn them! # Strain the juice from the lemons into a small saucepan, add the turmeric, ginger and sugar, and simmer for 2-3 minutes until the sugar has dissolved. If there isn't enough juice, add a tablespoon or two of water. # Add the spices and sugar mixture to the bowl of lemons, and mix together well. # Pack into a pint jar, pressing the pieces in if needed, to ensure that the liquid covers all the lemon pieces. # Set aside to mature for 1 month. ==Notes, tips and variations== * If you don't have fresh chilis, add some dried chilis or chili powder. The pickle in the photo has three whole dried chilis in it. [[Category:Indian recipes]] [[Category:Lemon recipes]] [[Category:Gluten-free recipes]] [[Category:Vegan recipes]]

It's important to understand how each iLife app fits in with the other five. After all, part of iLife's allure is that everything is tightly integrated.
====GarageBand is in charge of:==== * Making songs and podcasts. * Scoring videos made in iMovie.
====GarageBand provides:==== * iTunes with your own songs. * iWeb with your own podcasts. * iMovie with an application to score movies with.
====GarageBand relies on:==== * iPhoto to provide photos for podcasts. * iMovie to provide movies for scoring.
{{BookCat}}

GarageBand was developed by Apple under the direction of Gerhard Lengeling, formerly of the German company Emagic, makers of Logic Audio. (Emagic was acquired by Apple in July 2002.)
The application was announced during Steve Jobs's keynote speech at the Macworld Conference & Expo in San Francisco on 6 January 2004; musician John Mayer assisted with its demonstration.
GarageBand 2 was announced at the (2005) Macworld Conference & Expo on January 11, 2005. It shipped, as announced, around 22 January 2005. Major new features included the abilities to view and edit music in Musical Notation form, to record up to 8 tracks at once, to fix timing and pitch of recordings, to automate track pan position, master volume, and master pitch, to transpose both audio and MIDI, and to import MIDI files.
GarageBand 3, announced at 2006's Macworld Conference & Expo, includes a 'podcast studio', including the ability to use more than 200 effects and jingles, and integration with iChat for remote interviews.
The latest version of GarageBand is part of iLife '08. It incorporates the ability to separately record sections of a song such as bridges and chorus lines, support for automation of tempos and instruments, and a "Magic GarageBand" feature that includes a virtual jam session with a complete 3D view of the instruments.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* Symbol of the Hallows */ new section
revision.text:
== Gregorovitch and the wands ==
{{spoiler}}
Just as a reminder: We have to be very careful talking about why Voldy is looking for Gregorovitch. Although the reader doesn't yet know this, what Voldy wants specifically is the Elder Wand, which he is chasing back through the last person known to have had it: Gregorovitch. Harry doesn't find this out until March. Until we learn that the Hallows exist, we don't know that the Elder Wand exists either; and so we are working on the assumption that Voldy wants Gregorovitch to make him a wand. But we don't want to explicitly say this; as with Slughorn in the previous book, we should let the reader form their own, erroneous conclusion.
Note that I, at least, on hearing of the Hallows, thought that what Voldy was after was the Stone. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] <small>([[User talk:Chazz|talk]])</small> 17:11, 3 September 2007 (UTC)
== Luna and Barny Weasley ==
Why must people always found big hidden links and incredibly powerful secrets. There is not a clue in the all seven books that Luna Lovegood have any unexpected magical abilities. Is Ron secretly a cat animagus because he once won a Chess match against McGonagal enchanted pieces? Is Dudley the heir of Helga Huffulpuff because he let a CUP of tea beneath Harry's door in the second chapter? Harry have drink Polyjuice Potion and look has an hypothetical cousin Barny but he talks like Harry Potter (though with a different voice), he moves like Harry Potter... Luna clearly tell she recognises him from the way he act. The Death Eaters identify Harry between 7 decoys just because he act "Potter Style". Yes Luna is a little weird but if she succeed in Harry's indentification it's because, unlike other people, she's curious, open-minded and that she cares about people.
[[User:Melmoth|Melmoth]]<small>([[User talk:Melmoth|talk]])</small> 17:11, 25 September 2009 (UTC) :An interesting point. I think that it is a case of people seeing what they expect to see, perhaps. It's certainly true that Draco didn't identify Harry and Ron pretending to be Crabbe and Goyle; or, for that matter, Barty impersonating Moody. In those two cases, certainly it is possible that people saw who they expected to see, and in this case, "Barney Weasley" being a total unknown, they wouldn't have any expectations and would see what was actually there. Luna likely would recognize Harry because she is much more in this world than many others. If you don't mind, I will write that up. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] <small>([[User talk:Chazz|talk]])</small> 21:20, 27 March 2010 (UTC)
== Symbol of the Hallows ==
Should it be mentioned what the Hallows symbol is in the GP section? This would be a good place to talk about the Swastika allegory that is referenced loosely in the Questions section, too.

revision.comment: fixed signature and login on previous revision
revision.text: I don't understand nothing at all. THERE IS NO ONE USABLE SOURCE CODE ON HOW TO CREATE BIBLIOGRAPHY. What do I have to write in .tex and what to write in an outer .bib file. Please, write only ONE solution what is works. Just for the beginners. {{unsigned|Brtkr|20:43, 31 July 2012}} there is no copyright notice on the source page, or am i missing it. [[User:70.17.91.192|70.17.91.192]] 17:55, 3 September 2007 (UTC) :I don't think we need it: all the authors are properly referenced in [[LaTeX/Authors]]. [[User:Alejo2083|Alessio Damato]] 20:39, 4 September 2007 (UTC) The biblatex package is a recent addition to the bibliography process that allows greater flexibility than standard bibtex. It might be worthwhile to write a section about this package. We should mention \cite[pagenumber]{citekey} somewhere on this page. - This is there; but there is a contradiction between these instructions and the instructions on multiple references (possibly this is a fault with LaTeX and cannot be resolved here) When introducing the natbib package, the bibliographystyle is mentioned. But this is a concept related to BibTeX, that come later in the page. This can be confusing for the reader. Corrected Citavi entry. Citavi is straightforward commercial software (not free as claimed), which offers a size-limited version (100 entries) for free. The paragraph describing the \bibliography command mentions that you can specify a different directory - $HOME/.... This will not work. The $ will be interpreted as the start of a math element. == Bibliography styles: how to reduce vertical space between bibliography entries? == I wonder how to reduce the vertical space ''between'' bibtex entries - while I can reduce the linespace with the "setspace" packages (works fine) I don't manage to get more entries on a page... ? thanks for a hint, [[User:Bumbulski|Bumbulski]] ([[User talk:Bumbulski|talk]]) 19:07, 8 September 2009 (UTC) : Found it: the natbib style allows to define \bibsep. Redefine with (0pt is no line space between items; here: have a bit of space): \setlength{\bibsep}{3pt} [[User:Bumbulski|Bumbulski]] ([[User talk:Bumbulski|talk]]) 19:00, 9 September 2009 (UTC) The LaTeX code is too small, I think it would be better to enlarge it == Explain natbib earlier == Shouldn't Natbib be explained earlier in this chapter than at the very end? Switching from plain BibTeX to Natbib is a pain, while setting Natbib to numeric mode is quite easy. Elsevier uses Natbib for all LaTeX journals... [[User:Qwertyus|Qwertyus]] ([[User talk:Qwertyus|talk]]) 21:35, 22 October 2010 (UTC) == further reading == if there were a further reading section it ought to have a link to http://www.tug.org/TUGboat/tb30-1/tb94mori.pdf --[[Special:Contributions/87.127.117.246|87.127.117.246]] ([[User talk:87.127.117.246|discuss]]) 22:19, 3 February 2011 (UTC) == Correcting "Add the Bibliography to the Table of Contents as numbered item" == If I'm not mistaken, the tips provided here add an extra blank page before the bibliography (at least in the report document type). The solution to remove it seems to be provided here: http://www.latex-community.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=10573 Should this be mentioned? --[[Special:Contributions/192.54.144.229|192.54.144.229]] ([[User talk:192.54.144.229|discuss]]) 09:42, 20 July 2011 (UTC) Easiest way I've found to add bibliography to the TOC is: {{{ \renewcommand{\bibsection} {\chapter{\bibname}} }}} This works because usually the bibsection is chapter* (which has no toc entry). You can also modify this to use addcontentsline after the \bibname which is a mix of my solution and the one already used on the page. --[[User:Ayrn|Ayrn]] ([[User talk:Ayrn|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ayrn|contribs]]) 10:37, 20 March 2012 (UTC) == The mention of VIM at the end == There is mention of compiling the latex document and aux file with bibtex through vim. Though this is good, it seems misplaced. There could be a section devoted to integrating latex into different editors. Also, you can get bibtex to process the file more simply by using the command... !bibtex %< == Add BibLaTeX section? == Should BibLaTeX maybe be mentioned? [[User:Benregn|Benregn]] ([[User talk:Benregn|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Benregn|contribs]]) 18:53, 12 October 2011 (UTC) Definitly! Especialy the Multiple Biliographies part is worth noting about it. Its so easy to do it with biblatex: \printbibliography[title={Book references},type=book] \printbibliography[title={Article references},type=article] \printbibliography[title={Other references}, nottype=article, nottype=book] That's it. --[[User:Wombalton|Wombalton]] ([[User talk:Wombalton|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Wombalton|contribs]]) 22:15, 12 November 2013 (UTC) == Alphabeticising "von" names == The '''John von Neumann''' example is actually more complicated than discussed here. I don't know about JvN in particular, but often people with de Surname, von Surname and van Surname like it to appear as "(de|von|van) Surname, Firstname" BUT they want to be alphabeticised under the first letter of Surname (so, N for JvN), not under d for "de" or "v" for "(von|van)". This page doesn't seem to deal with this issue, and probably should. Likewise, examples for name postfixes that aren't part of the surname, like the researcher Hal Duamé III[http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~hal/] or Firstname Surname Jr. [[User:Thayvian|Thayvian]] ([[User talk:Thayvian|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thayvian|contribs]]) 02:10, 28 May 2012 (UTC) == Fields not displayed == I had a problem when copying-pasting templates from this article. With the following template, the "year" filed was not displayed in my document. @article{Xarticle, author = "", title = "", journal = "", %volume = "", %number = "", %pages = "", year = "XXXX", %month = "", %note = "", } But with this template, it was: @article{Xarticle, author = "", title = "", journal = "", year = "XXXX", %volume = "", %number = "", %pages = "", %month = "", %note = "", } It seems to be linked to the position of the fields with "%". Can anybody confirm ? If this is the case it would have to be mentioned in the article. == Mention something about biber? == Biber is being used more frequently and recommended more often now (http://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/35233/bibtex-and-chicago-style-citations). Should this article be extended to have a quick blurb about biber? == thebibliography environment is not supported by texlipse == I took a decent while for me to figure this one out. That example at the top of the page does not work. An introductory example should be as accessible as possible, I think. At least we should warn texlipse users about this.[[Special:Contributions/130.234.207.147|130.234.207.147]] ([[User talk:130.234.207.147|discuss]]) 14:10, 21 September 2013 (UTC) == Underscore == Maybe it should be mentioned somewhere that it is not a good idea to use the underscore character in your bibtexkey (as is written in "Getting current LaTeX document to use your .bib file"). Apparently Latex doesn't like it much when you \cite{bibtex_key} [[Special:Contributions/131.180.138.34|131.180.138.34]] ([[User talk:131.180.138.34|discuss]]) 10:56, 28 November 2013 (UTC) :Can you be more specific? Every single key in my main .bib has 1 or more underscores and it works fine, all I can find by googling is that starting a key with underscore is anissue. [[User:ChrisHodgesUK|ChrisHodgesUK]] ([[User talk:ChrisHodgesUK|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ChrisHodgesUK|contribs]]) 12:32, 28 November 2013 (UTC) == Merge == The page [[LaTeX/More Bibliographies]] is mostly redundent and far less complete than [[LaTeX/Bibliography Management]]. It should be merged into it. --[[User:Ambrevar|Ambrevar]] ([[User talk:Ambrevar|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ambrevar|contribs]]) 09:00, 31 March 2014 (UTC) == Babelbib inconsistent name ordering == Maybe the section "Localizing bibliography appearance" should include a paragraph about how to customize how babelbib writes names in bibliography entries. Because the babelbib styles (e.g. babplain) writes the first author as "Lastname, Forename" and subsequent authors as "Forename Lastname" to emphasize its ordering by lastname. However there exists additional style variants suffixed with "-fl" (e.g. babplain-fl) or "-lf" to consistently writes names as respectively "Forename Lastname" or "Lastname, Forename". See "4 Available bibliography styles" in the bablebib documentation (http://mirrors.ctan.org/biblio/bibtex/contrib/babelbib/babelbib.pdf) for more information. [[User:Johslarsen|Johslarsen]] ([[User talk:Johslarsen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Johslarsen|contribs]])

==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. Feel free to ask me any questions you may have on my talk page. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.
''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 18:45, 3 September 2007 (UTC)

Hi Chemical Engineer, welcome to Wikibooks. I've seen your edits to the [[ICEP]] book and they are impressive! Are you currently in school or in the field?
It seems like you have a good handle on how the wiki works, here's some links that may help you in the future though:
{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see the [[Help:Editing|editing guide]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.
Good luck! [[User:Mattb112885|Mattb112885]] <small> ([[User talk:Mattb112885|talk to me]]) </small> 19:34, 3 September 2007 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Ingredients */ Added "patty" after hamburger to avoid confusion.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Hawaii|Cuisine of Hawaii]]
==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:egg|eggs]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Hamburger|hamburger]] patty * 1 cup of [[Cookbook:rice|rice]] * [[Cookbook:Gravy|gravy]]
==Procedure==
# Cook the 2 eggs sunny side up. # Cook up the hamburger to your preference. # Boil the cup of rice, heat up the gravy. # Assemble in this manner: #* rice on bottom; #* hamburger on top of that; #* then the eggs; #* pour the gravy all over the top.
Result -- an awesome Loco Moco. Ono!
[[Category:Hawaiian recipes]] [[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Egg recipes]]

revision.comment: Welcome! and a file copyright notice.
revision.text:
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Jennamr14!
[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' about the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|interests you]]. If you're coming here from other Wikimedia projects, you should read [[Help:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|our primer for Wikimedians]] to get quickly up-to-speed.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* See the '''Wikibooks [[Help:Contents|help pages]]''' for common issues. * Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Wikibooks:Reverting|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]].
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[:w:Help:Edit summary|the edit summary]] and [[Help:Show preview|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[Help:Talk page|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks, [[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 14:58, 28 April 2009 (UTC)
(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
== Copyright problems with [[:{{#ifeq:{{NAMESPACE:File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg}}||File:File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg|File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg}}]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thank you for uploading [[:{{#ifeq:{{NAMESPACE:File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg}}||File:File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg|File:1McGlamory,Clay-BAL XI.jpg}}]]. See '''[[Help:Uploading Images]]''' for help and [{{fullurl:Special:Contributions|contribs=user&target={{PAGENAMEE}}&namespace=6}} this page] for a list of your file namespace contributions. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask in the [[WB:HELP|assistance reading room]]. Thank you. [[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 14:58, 28 April 2009 (UTC)}}

==Image copyright problem with [[:Image:KM groupA1.jpg]]== Thanks for uploading [[:Image:KM groupA1.jpg]]. The [[w:Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia Foundation]] is very careful about the images included in Wikibooks because of [[w:United States copyright law|copyright law]], and requires that we maintain a strict [[Wikibooks:Copyright|copyright policy]]. The image that may soon be deleted unless we can determine the copyright holder and status. The copyright holder is usually the creator, the creator's employer, or the last person who was transferred ownership rights. Copyright information on images is signified using copyright templates. The three basic license types on Wikibooks are [[w:open content|open content]], [[w:public domain|public domain]], and [[w:fair use|fair use]]. Find the appropriate template in [[Wikibooks:Image copyright tags]] and place it on the image page like this: {{TemplateName}}. Please signify the copyright information on any other images you have uploaded or will upload. Remember that images without this important information or giving false information can be deleted by an administrator. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask another Wikibookian at the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|help desk]]. Thank you. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 01:44, 4 September 2007 (UTC)

'''This is a test page for Snea Thinsan'''
== I am only aiming to show my students how to start and edit a page. ==
[[Image:http://i83.photobucket.com/albums/j297/piangdin/dragon.jpg]]

Back to [[Past LSAT Explained]] ==Section I Analytical Reasoning== ==Section II Logical Reasoning== ===Question 01=== ===Question 02=== ===Question 03=== ===Question 04=== IDENTIFY This ia a flaw question. The keyword here is "questionable" in the question. READ Politician P, as most politicians do, is attacking his opponent's claim. He states his oponent's claim in the first sentence and attacks it in the second sentence and argues that his opponent is "mistaken". His reasoning is that raising taxes upsets the taxpayers because of the loss of purchasing power and therefore, it is wrong. ANALYZE His reasoning is that whatever makes people upset, it is wrong. It is a questionable logic because anything that lead to a number of people becoming upset is deemed "simple mistaken". CHOOSE Let's go through the answer response one by one. (A) Incorrect. P does not presupposes that the claim is wrong. P has a reason for it. Moreover, no "other unpopular views" is mentioned here. Raising tax may be a unpopular view but there is nothing else. (B) Incorrect. There is no attack on character here. The politician only describes the effect of the claim that people would be upset. '''(C) Correct.''' Right on target. P argues that raising tax (or the implementation of the claim) would lead to unhappiness (many taxpayers becoming upset). (D) Incorrect. There is no irrelvant issue in the argument. (E) Incorrect. P actually argues that the obligation does not exist. This choice is for the people who misread the question, thinking that the task is to find the flaw in the opponent's reasoning not Politician P's. Be careful. ===Question 05=== ===Question 06=== ===Question 07=== ===Question 08=== ===Question 09=== ===Question 10=== ===Question 11=== ===Question 12=== ===Question 13=== ===Question 14=== ===Question 15=== IDENTIFY This is a flaw question. READ The editorialist argues that if one is mature enough to handle the responsibilities, then we can give the person the previleges. Previledges entail responsibilities. Then the editorialists cite a scientific fact that people are physically mature by 17. ANALYZE He mistakenly equates physical maturity with all around maturity. Just because one is physically mature does not mean the person is capable in all regards. You can't run for U.S. president or the Senate when you are 18. You can't even buy alochol legally in the States. CHOOSE (A) Incorrect. The argument does not assume what it sets out to prove. If this is the case, it would be a circular reasoning and easy to spot. (B) Incorrect. The weakness is not in the small number of examples. The evidence the editorialist uses is pretty powerful. "Science has established" he says. He implies that there have been conclusive research findings to support this to be a generally accepted theory. '''(C) Correct.''' You need to remember the definition of "equivocate" which is like beating around the bush. The editorialist confuses us by implying that physically maturity is all that is required for accepting adult's responsibilities, which isn't true. He is playing with the central concept of maturity. (D) Incorrect. There is no authority here. He did not appeal to some eminent scientist. Even if there exists some goddess of science, she is not an inappropriate authority. She would be the authority. Therefore, this choice is clearly wrong. (E) Incorrect. This is a side issue. The editorialist's argument is consistent with this choice since it could be true that most are mature by 17 while some are mature at 16. So this choice does not weaken the argument. ===Question 16=== IDENTIFY
This is a parrell reasoning question. You might want to consider skipping if you are not very good at this type of questions or low on time. READ
Read carefully for the structure. ANALYZE
Use your logic game diagramming skill to briefly sketch the structure. All A -> commercial or critical All critical -> commercial All A -> commercial or commercial (substitute critical with commercial) All A -> commercial CHOOSE
(A) Incorrect. The word "Most" ruins it. The passage says "every new play". This choice is not a 100% foolproof logic because "most" opens a hole. (B) Incorrect. '''(C) Correct.''' (D) Incorrect. (E) Incorrect. ===Question 17=== ===Question 18=== ===Question 19=== ===Question 20=== ===Question 21=== IDENTIFY This is a flaw question. READ Mr. Ziegler is on trial for shooting. His lawyer argues that his client is not guilty because he was insane when he fired the shot. The lawyer points out that the plaintiff did not prove (probably could not) that he was sane during the firing but only provided evidence that he is sane after the incident. ANALYZE The attonery does not see the link between the defendant's sanity after the crime and his mental state before the crime. If he is sane now, why wouldn't he be sane then? His sanity after the crime sugguests a strong probability that he was sane then. CHOOSE (A) Incorrect. We do not known Ziegler's professional qualification or educational background. The attorney does not raise this point. (B) Incorrect. The lawyer does not conclude that there is a lack of evidence for his sanity- in fact, there is as the plaintiff submitted. The attorney does not provide any evidence against his sanity. He concludes that Ziegler is insane for lack of evidence in contrary. (C) Incorrect. Ziegler's consulting firm may be worried about this point but this is not relevant. (D) Incorrect. Moral responsibility is not an issue here. Legal culpability is. Moreover, this response does not address any flaw in the reasoning. '''(E) Correct.''' Bingo. His sanity later indicates that he may be sane before. ===Question 22=== ===Question 23=== ===Question 24=== IDENTIFY This is a disagreement question. As the passage above indicates Monica and Hector are arguing about something. READ ===Question 25=== ==Section III Logical Reasoning== ===Question 01=== ===Question 02=== ===Question 03=== ===Question 04=== ===Question 05=== ===Question 06=== ===Question 07=== ===Question 08=== ===Question 09=== ===Question 10=== ===Question 11=== ===Question 12=== ===Question 13=== ===Question 14=== ===Question 15=== ===Question 16=== ===Question 17=== ===Question 18=== ===Question 19=== ===Question 20=== ===Question 21=== ===Question 22=== ===Question 23=== ===Question 24=== ===Question 25=== ==Section IV Reading Comprehension== '''Passage I'''
compulsory national service
'''Passage II'''
[http://www.portercolloquium.org/ James Porter] and African American Art
'''Passage III'''
Dolphin
'''Passage IV'''
[http://www.umd.umich.edu/casl/hum/eng/classes/434/geweb/PROPERTY.htm Susan Staves]

We welcome and appreciate your contributions, such as [[:Past LSAT Explained]], but we regretfully cannot accept [[Wikibooks:Copyrights|copyrighted]] works borrowed from either websites or printed material, or works which use an unacceptable license. For more information, please read [[Wikibooks:Media]]. Thanks and Happy editing! '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 02:37, 27 October 2007 (UTC)}}

'''THINK LIKE THE TESTMAKERS''' The LSAT is a test of your way of thinking. It tests how well you think like the testmakers. Once you start to think like them, you can be thought as having the LSAT mind. Your preparation of the LSAT should therefore focus on learning to this way of thinking.
==Logical Reasoning== This PrepTest explanation for Logical Reasoning sections follows a methodology called IRAC(pronounced EYE-rack) which stands for: '''Identify, Read, Analyze, and Choose'''. It is a step by step methodology for tackling LSAT questions.
'''Identify'''
The IRAC starts with quickly scanning the question. Most LSAT questions start with a brief passage or statement followed by a question. It is important to figure out exactly what the question is looking for. You may decide to skip the question if you are low on time or the question seems too difficult. You can choose to guess random.
'''Read'''
You need to move to the beginning of the passage and quickly and accurately work the passage. Underline, paraphrase and engage with the passage. Using symbols to mark the passage. Do not overanalyze or bring outside information or knowledge but stick to what's provided.
'''Analyze'''
Use your LSAT analytical skill. Apply the right analysis required by the question. You are not given credit for doing something else. Once you are done with analyzing the passage, move to each response.
'''Choose'''
==Reading Comprehension== This PrepTest explanation for Reading Comprehension sections follows a methodology called BRIEF (you are essentially briefing the passage) which stands for: '''Break, Read, Internalize, Eliminate, Find'''. It is a step by step methodology for tackling LSAT questions.
'''Break'''
Go to the questions and figure out the key terms and words. You are essentially breaking the question. When you read, pay a special attention to those words and relationship.
'''Read'''
Scan quickly and visualize a chart in your brain.
'''Internalize'''
Digest what you read.
'''Eliminate'''
Do not look for the right answer. Look for the wrong one first.
'''Find'''
Mark your answer sheet and move on.
==Analytical Reasoning== This PrepTest explanation for Analytical Reasoning sections follows a methodology called CASES which stands for: '''Chart, Analyze, S, Eliminate, Select'''. It is a step by step methodology for tackling LSAT questions.
'''Chart'''
'''Analyze'''
S '''Eliminate'''
'''Select'''

{{C sharp/Navigation|Keywords|extern}} __TOC__ The keyword {{C sharp|extern}} indicates that the method being called exists in a [[:w:Dynamic-link library|DLL]]. A tool called tlbimp.exe can create a wrapper assembly that allows C# to interact with the DLL like it was a .NET assembly i.e. use constructors to instantiate it, call its methods. Older DLLs will not work with this method. Instead, you have to explicitally tell the compiler what DLL to call, what method to call and what parameters to pass. Since parameter type is very important, you can also explicitally define what type the parameter should be passed to the method as. Here is an example: using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; namespace ExternKeyword { public class Program { static void Main() { NativeMethods.MessageBoxEx(IntPtr.Zero, "Hello there", "Caption here", 0, 0); } } public class NativeMethods { [DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern MessageBoxEx(IntPtr hWnd, string lpText, string lpCaption, uint uType, short wLanguageId); } } The {{C sharp|[DllImport("user32.dll")]}} tells the compiler which DLL to reference. Windows searches for files as defined by the PATH environment variable, and therefore will search those paths before failing. The method is also static because the DLL may not understand how to be "created", as DLLs can be created in different languages. This allows the method to be called directly, instead of being instantiated and then used. {{C sharp/Keywords}} [[Category:C Sharp Programming|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary| | Category = Appetizer recipes | Servings = 6 to 8 slices | Time = 5 minutes | Rating = 1 }}
'''Field Dreams''' is an eclectic yet easy to make appetizer. The unusual flavors and ingredient combination makes this an excellent way to start a dinner party.
==Ingredients== *2 Golden Delicious [[Cookbook:Apple|apples]] *Yellow [[Cookbook:Mustard|mustard]] as served on hot dogs *1 oz crumbly, fresh goat [[Cookbook:cheese|cheese]]
==Procedure== #Wash the apples and cut across (i.e. not from top to bottom) into slices 1/4 inch thick. Preferably the apples should come from the refrigerator as the cold temperature will add to the contrast. #Cover one side of the apple slices with yellow mustard. #Crumble the goat cheese onto each slice. #Serve immediately as is.
Makes 6 to 8 slices.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Tip 1: Golden delicious apples are preferable, yet any sweet, crisp apple will do. *Tip 2: Add honey roasted nuts of some kind along with the goat cheese for an interesting combination. *Tip 3: For a professional look, lay each slice of apple on lettuce or another type of garnish.
{{DEFAULTSORT:{{PAGENAME}}}} [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Egg recipes|8|1 hour|2}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Southern cuisine|Southern cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Cheese|Cheese]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|Bread recipes]]
=Egg Pie=
==Ingredients==
* 2 strips [[Cookbook:Bacon|bacon]] * 24 [[Cookbook:Hard Tack|soda crackers]] (2 inch squares) * 6 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * ⅛ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * Dash of [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]], cut into small pieces. * [[Cookbook:Cooking Spray|cooking spray]] * [[Cookbook:Jam|Jam]] or [[Cookbook:jelly|jelly]], optional
==Procedure==
# Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|350°F]]. # Cut bacon into small pieces and [[Cookbook:Sauté|sauté]] until brown. # Crush crackers. # Beat eggs in bowl. # Add crackers, milk, salt, and pepper, then cheese. # Spray casserole dish with cooking spray # Pour mixture into casserole dish and add bacon. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until a knife comes out clean when pie is tested. # Cut in wedges and serve with jam.
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* You can dice, shred, or just cut up the cheese; the smaller the pieces, the more evenly it will mix.
==Uses==
* Good dish for breakfast, brunch, or late night snack dish.
